title: Panel Discussion: “What Actions for Greatest Impact?”
segmentation: Good afternoon actually.
I do feel very much at home and I'm very happy to be here and for me it is a great pleasure but also an enormous honor to to moderate this particular panel entitled.
What what the actions for greatest impact?
I know it comes at the end of the busy day, Ann.
You must be tired, but I'm sure I will sure that I will.
I do assure you that the special expertise of each one of our panelists will attract your attention and you will find this session dynamic.
Especially since we will have a long.
Discussion period so we can have a dialogue.
But before I introduce them properly, I want to take you back some 15 years ago at the beginning of the century.
Doesn't that sound long ago?
At that time, the newly appointed Director General of UNESCO, Japan.
Squishy to matura.
Wanted to make a difference.
With great pride he presented to us his staff two newly appointed assistant Director Generals, the first Abdul Khan.
Was coming from his post in India as Vice Chancellor of IGNOU in the Indira Gandhi National Open University.
He was to lead the communication sector of UNESCO.
The second Sir John Daniel had just finished his term as Vice Chancellor of the Open University UK.
Ann would head the education sector.
Matura believed that you tell Technologies will have helped transform education.
In the world, by bringing it by bringing education to those that needed it most.
In developing countries and the close cooperation between two UNESCO sectors led by two eminent experts from real world with real world experience would make this happen.
Many great I.
Ideas often failed with time, but this is one that took a life of its own.
The appointment of the two 80 GS at UNESCO in 2001 coincided with a significant technological development.
The launch of the MIT Open Courseware are evolutionary step that involved make making their lectures notes freely available on the web.
Some viewed this as a huge opportunity for access to quality education.
Others questioned whether this was another form or of Neo imperialism.
Now, how could her developing countries best to profit and benefit from this innovation?

To examine that the educational UNESCO's communication sector led by Abdul Khan and he was there, convened a forum in 2010, two at which John Daniel asked me to represent the education sector and this forum.

Made history Cathy Casserly, a founding architect, Avoyelles who's also member of our panel, then at the Culet Foundation, was the key person at the forum during which the term open educational resources was coined.
And here we are, 15 years later.
Proud that the decision of UNESCO to engage with open courseware, O ER for the benefit of develop.
In countries has grown to become a grassroots movement through a worldwide or your community of practitioners.
To which Susan Dantoni of Unicycles IEP did much to Foster, as did the UNESCO chairs on all.
We are one of which is the Co organizer of this of this conference.
This Congress here today in Ljubljana.
It also engaged the government through commitments to follow up the 2010.
12 Paris declaration Today we are faced with an even greater challenge which is to move from commitment to action, especially in the perspective of ovr contribute.
I think to achieving the UN Sustainable Development Goals as stipulated in the Ancient Declaration and this has been repeated many times.
But it is a very important step forward.
So now let me introduce the panelists properly.
Doctor Catherine Casserly Kathy a pracademic pracademic.
I have had to look at in the dictionary, which is a practitioner and an academic.
Will speak first and among her numerous activities as a researcher and practitioner.
She was the founding architect of Ovr of the Ovr Field and she developed, managed and launched the Hundred $1,000,000 in ocular.
Portfolio support for OER at the Hewlett Foundation.
She didn't move to this to be CEO and President of Creative Commons at the time when it developed its international license, which was also crucial for UNESCO.
Now she's back as lead as the interim ovr lead at the Hewlett Foundation, where I'm sure she will lead the Oreore movement to new Heights internationally.
She will then be followed.
Goodbye Abdul Wahid Khan, former vice chancellor of IGNOU and Assistant director general for Communication and Information that UNESCO.

After leaving UNESCO, continuing his commitment to empowering people through access to information and knowledge of Duncan, is currently helping Buniyad India, a charitable foundation to improve quality of education in remote rural areas.
He is also president of Knowledge Group and educational organization in Canada.
The final.
Or end with comments from Sir John Daniel, who spent the 1st.
30 years of his career in universities where his major concern was to promote open education.
After that he worked at 2 international organizations.

UNESCO's assistant director General for Education and at school as president and CEO, and in this function he was responsible for guiding the preparations of the first UNESCO World Congress on IR, which led to the adoption by acclamation.
By acclamation of the Paris, 2012 oh yard declaration.
Finally, let me in.
Reduce myself, although this has been done before so I am stomach overly strong beach.
I had the pleasure and privilege of making this 15 year journey alongside our panelists promoting the Ovr movement by heading the section of higher education at UNESCO.
And being the lead consultant to call for the 2012 or we are Congress.
So with that, I invite Kathy to come and make her presentation.
